item.title: Italy Opens New Bridge, Two Years After Deadly Collapse
item.description: Italy inaugurates a new bridge on a highway connecting the port city of Genoa to France, almost two years after its predecessor collapsed, killing 43 people and shining a light on the dilapidated state of the country’s infrastructure.

item.title: Covid Supercharges Federal Reserve as Backup Lender to the World
item.description: When the coronavirus halted the global economy in March, the U.S. central bank lent massively to counterparts abroad. The action—among its most significant expansions of power yet—cemented the dollar’s dominance.

item.title: Microsoft's Talks With TikTok Raise Ire in China
item.description: Washington’s ultimatum to the Chinese owner of TikTok—sell the app’s American operations to Microsoft or leave the country—is hardening suspicions in China that the U.S. aims to sabotage the country’s efforts to grow its own technology.

item.title: Islamic State Claims Responsibility for Deadly Attack on Afghan Prison
item.description: Islamic State claimed responsibility for storming a prison in eastern Afghanistan holding hundreds of its members, in an attack that killed at least 29 people and allowed numerous inmates to escape.

item.title: In a City Built on the Slave Trade, Britain's Oldest Black Community Seeks a Reckoning
item.description: Liverpool has tried harder than most British cities to face up to its past as Europe’s biggest slaving port, but activists and locals say this hasn’t translated into improved fortunes for the Black community.

item.title: Israel Says it Thwarted Attack Along Its Border with Syria
item.description: Israeli special forces fired on four men it says were planting explosive devices along the frontier as tensions rise with Hezbollah.
